title: Webkit Transitions on SVG attributes
description: Learn how to add webkit transition to svg attributes, for example bar charts. Technically, the animation will be based on a setInterval() loop.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Upper respiratory tract infection (e.g., streptococcal pharyngitis)
Bacterial or viral meningitis or encephalitis
Rickettsial diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
Viral Infection (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Epstein-Barr Virus)
Sjögren's Syndrome with renal and nervous system involvement
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)
Leukemia (especially acute types with cutaneous involvement)

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV/AIDS can present with lymphadenopathy, episodic weakness, and in advanced cases, individuals may experience secondary infections leading to symptoms like vaginitis. Fever or hyperthermia can occur in acute infection or as part of an AIDS-related infection.

diagnoses.name: Chlamydia/Gonorrhea
diagnoses.reasoning: Both chlamydia and gonorrhea can cause lymphadenopathy and vaginitis. While less directly associated, systemic symptoms can occasionally include fever (hyperthermia).

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus)
diagnoses.reasoning: Mononucleosis can cause significant lymphadenopathy, fever, and in some cases, spleen enlargement that can lead to episodic weakness. Direct links to vaginitis and hemorrhoids are less common but potential systemic effects could loosely relate.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Lymphoma can present with lymphadenopathy, episodic weakness, and fever. While not typically associated with vaginitis or hemorrhoids, systemic effects of cancer or its treatments can sometimes manifest broadly.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can cause lymphadenopathy and fever. Episodic weakness could relate to general fatigue common in SLE. SLE may indirectly affect vaginal health due to its systemic nature and potential for creating an immunocompromised state, though not typically presenting with vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.reasoning: Secondary syphilis can lead to lymphadenopathy and fever. Lesions associated with syphilis might be confused with or contribute to symptoms of vaginitis. Although less common, syphilis can have systemic effects leading to various symptoms including episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
diagnoses.reasoning: Primarily an outcome of untreated sexually transmitted infections, PID can cause symptoms like vaginitis. While more directly associated with pelvic symptoms, systemic spread can occasionally lead to lymphadenopathy and fever.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Tuberculosis, particularly extrapulmonary, can cause lymphadenopathy and fever. While episodic weakness is a common symptom of general tuberculosis infection, direct association with vaginitis or hemorrhoids is rare but possible in disseminated disease.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Behçet's disease can cause systemic inflammation leading to symptoms like episodic fever (hyperthermia) and lymphadenopathy. Although more known for ulcers in the genital area, symptoms could be confused with vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Sarcoidosis can present with lymphadenopathy and fever. While episodic weakness could be part of the general fatigue associated with sarcoidosis, the direct correlation with vaginitis and hemorrhoids is not typical but possible due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Viral Upper Respiratory Tract Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Common colds and other upper respiratory tract infections can cause symptoms like sinusitis (sinus inflammation) and chest pain due to coughing. Viral infections can also result in rashes.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Allergic reactions to environmental triggers can lead to sinusitis and rashes. While it does not directly cause chest pain or presyncope, the discomfort and nasal congestion could contribute to these symptoms in a more indirect manner.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.reasoning: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition that can cause onychodystrophy (nail dystrophy) and rashes. It can also lead to psoriatic arthritis, which might be connected with chest pain if it involves the chest wall.

diagnoses.name: Eczema
diagnoses.reasoning: Eczema, or atopic dermatitis, can lead to skin rashes and occasionally secondary infections that might manifest as chest pain due to involvement of deeper skin layers or associated lymph nodes. Onychodystrophy can also occur in chronic cases.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can cause rashes, chest pain (due to pleurisy or pericarditis), and onychodystrophy. The symptoms like presyncope could arise from cardiovascular involvement.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: Reactive arthritis can cause chest pain (if the heart or lungs are involved), rashes, and sometimes onychodystrophy. Presyncope might be less directly related but could occur due to overall inflammation or if the cardiovascular system is affected.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Sarcoidosis involves the growth of granulomas in various body parts, potentially causing sinusitis, chest pain (due to lung involvement), rashes, and less commonly onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Transmitted by ticks, Lyme disease can manifest with rashes (erythema migrans), onychodystrophy as a more rare symptom, and various cardiac symptoms that could explain chest pain and presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reactions
diagnoses.reasoning: Adverse reactions to medications can cause rashes, sinusitis (as a part of a systemic reaction), chest pain (if there's cardiac involvement), and onychodystrophy (through toxic effects on the nails).

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV infection, progressing to AIDS, can manifest with sinusitis, rashes, onychodystrophy (due to opportunistic infections or drug reactions), and potentially chest pain (due to opportunistic infections affecting the lungs). Presyncope could also result from the overall weakened state.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It may go along with symptoms like vulvodynia and restless legs.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis is a disease of the central nervous system that can cause cognitive problems, muscle stiffness/spasticity, and autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Small Fiber Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Small fiber neuropathy involves the damage to the small nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system and can lead to pain, restless legs, and autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue in many parts of the body. Symptoms might include cognitive difficulties, skin rashes, and eosinophilia.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It can also affect other parts of the body, including the nervous system, causing cognitive issues and peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that destroys bile ducts in the liver. It's associated with fatigue, memory problems, and it can coexist with conditions such as Sjögren's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism can lead to a variety of symptoms including cognitive issues, fatigue, and can also contribute to eosinophilia. It's a condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Iron deficiency anemia can lead to symptoms such as memory problems and restless legs syndrome. It occurs when the body doesn't have enough iron to produce adequate red blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A form of dysautonomia that is characterized by an increased heart rate when standing up. POTS can also cause brain fog, fatigue, and leg pain.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: A condition affecting the stomach and intestines, characterized by an elevated number of eosinophils. It can be associated with dysautonomia and gastrointestinal symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) in early stage or with preserved function

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Sexually transmitted infections (e.g., gonorrhea, chlamydia causing vaginitis)
Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Mouth
Sjögren's Syndrome (potential cause of Dry Eyes)
Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia (potential cause of Monocytosis)
Viral Infection (potential cause of Monocytosis and Pneumonia)
Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Rheumatoid Arthritis, related to Sjögren's Syndrome and monocytosis)
Heart Failure (potential outcome of untreated or severe Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy)

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Leukocytosis often signifies an infection. In someone presenting with bronchitis, a secondary bacterial infection could be a cause, impacting appetite and potentially exacerbating muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Bronchitis and leukocytosis may indicate a viral infection, which can lead to systemic effects such as muscle pain and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.reasoning: Influenza can cause bronchitis, leukocytosis, muscle pain, and decreased appetite, suggesting it as a potential diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: While not directly causing leukocytosis, chronic fatigue syndrome could explain muscle pain, decreased appetite, and may be secondary to chronic infection or inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: In the context of endometriosis, already indicating a pelvic issue, and leukocytosis suggestive of an infection, this could explain systemic symptoms like decreased appetite and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Some autoimmune diseases can lead to leukocytosis, cause symptoms like muscle pain, and could exacerbate endometriosis through systemic inflammation, indirectly affecting appetite.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis-Associated Ovarian Cancer
diagnoses.reasoning: Leukocytosis might be a sign of cancer, and endometriosis increases the risk for ovarian cancer, which could also lead to decreased appetite and generalized symptoms like muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reasoning: Although it doesn't usually cause leukocytosis, fibromyalgia could be considered for muscle pain and decreased appetite as secondary symptoms. The diagnosis is more supportive in excluding other causes.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Bronchitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic bronchitis could explain the bronchitis and leukocytosis, potentially related to a chronic infection, which might also affect general well-being, including appetite and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Tuberculosis can cause leukocytosis and bronchitis symptoms. It is a serious condition that also affects overall health, leading to decreased appetite and muscle pain.

diagnoses: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
Shock (various types, e.g., hypovolemic, septic, cardiogenic)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Neurogenic bladder leading to urinary incontinence accompanied by other systemic failures
Asthma exacerbation triggered by an allergic reaction
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis) with extraintestinal manifestations
Viral gastroenteritis with accompanying allergic reaction or dermatologic condition

diagnoses.explanation: Migraines can cause phonophobia, scotoma, and vomiting. Aura can sometimes manifest as aphasia or hearing loss.
Characterized by hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo (which may lead to vomiting), but less commonly linked to aphasia or scotoma.
A stroke can cause sudden hearing loss, scotoma, vomiting, aphasia, and sometimes sensitivity to sound depending on the area of the brain affected.
Depending on its location, a brain tumor can cause hearing loss, scotoma (by pressing on optic nerve or pathways), vomiting (especially in the morning), phonophobia, and aphasia.
MS can lead to various neurological symptoms depending on the location of lesions, including scotoma (visual disturbances), aphasia, and less commonly, hearing loss and vomiting.

Similar to migraines, vestibular migraines can cause phonophobia, and occasional hearing loss, and are associated with vertigo that may lead to vomiting. Scotoma and aphasia are less typical but possible.

This benign tumor on the auditory nerve can cause hearing loss, and some patients might experience vomiting due to increased intracranial pressure, with aphasia, phonophobia, and scotoma being less common.

While less common, this condition can lead to sudden vision loss (scotoma), hearing loss, and less frequently, symptoms like vomiting. Aphasia and phonophobia are not typically associated but can be seen in complex cases with significant cerebral involvement.
Some forms of epilepsy can lead to aphasia, phonophobia during or after a seizure, and less commonly, hearing loss or scotoma. Vomiting is not typical but can occur postictally.

Infections like meningitis or encephalitis can cause a combination of these symptoms, including vomiting, hearing loss, scotoma (from increased intracranial pressure or direct involvement), and in severe cases, aphasia.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause nonscarring alopecia, hemolytic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and arthropathy among its varied manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often accompanies other immune system disorders like lupus and rheumatoid arthritis, and can feature peripheral neuropathy and arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can be associated with systemic symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, which can cause peripheral neuropathy, arthropathy, and in some cases hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs in the body, presenting symptoms including arthropathy and peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to numerous symptoms, including arthropathy and potentially peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness that can cause a wide range of symptoms, depending on the stage of the disease, including arthropathy and peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiency in B12 can lead to a form of anemia known as megaloblastic anemia and can also cause peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that can lead to liver inflammation, sometimes associated with extrahepatic manifestations like arthropathy and peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immune deficiency syndrome can have a broad range of presentations, including hemolytic anemia, nonscarring alopecia, peripheral neuropathy, and sometimes arthropathy.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C Associated Cryoglobulinemia
